verses.text: Then the LORD said to Noah, "Go into the ark, you and all your household, for I have seen that you are righteous before me in this generation."
verses.comment: God’s call to Noah underscores personal righteousness as well as stewardship of the household—foreshadowing the covenantal role of family and faith community. In Christian tradition, the ark becomes a powerful symbol of salvation.

verses.text: Take with you seven pairs of every clean animal, the male and his mate, and two of every animal that is not clean, the male and his mate.
verses.comment: ‘Clean’ animals reflect future sacrificial and worship practices. The distinction anticipates ritual purity laws developed later in Leviticus.

verses.text: Also take seven pairs of the birds of the air, male and female, to keep their kind alive on the surface of the earth.
verses.comment: Careful preservation of species highlights God’s order; birds are included for continuity in creation and future offerings.

verses.text: For in seven days I will make it rain on the earth for forty days and forty nights, and every living thing that I have made I will blot out from the face of the ground.
verses.comment: The forty-day period is echoed in other significant events (Moses, Elijah, Jesus in the wilderness), symbolizing preparation and trial before renewal.

verses.text: And Noah did all that the LORD commanded him.
verses.comment: Noah’s obedience sets a pattern for faith responding to God’s will, pointing toward the later call to be doers of the Word (James 1:22).

verses.text: Noah was six hundred years old when the floodwaters came upon the earth.
verses.comment: The age highlights the long lifespans before the flood—a point of spiritual reflection on the human condition and God’s timing.

verses.text: And Noah and his sons and his wife and his sons’ wives went with him into the ark to escape the waters of the flood.
verses.comment: Family enters the ark together, deepening the motif of salvation being extended through chosen generations—echoes of covenant and spiritual household.

verses.text: Of clean animals, and of animals that are not clean, and of birds, and of everything that creeps on the ground,
verses.comment: The catalog of animals reflects the order of creation and the commanded care for all living things.

verses.text: two and two, male and female, went into the ark with Noah, as God had commanded Noah.
verses.comment: Male and female echoes God’s purpose in creation, pointing to the sanctity of marital union as foundation for life and future generations.

verses.text: And after seven days, the waters of the flood came upon the earth.
verses.comment: The seven-day interval may foreshadow later biblical ritual days—an anticipation of sacred cycles in worship and cleansing.

verses.text: In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month, on that day all the fountains of the great deep burst forth, and the windows of the heavens were opened.
verses.comment: Cosmic scale of the flood—earth and heaven—reinforces the universal scope of judgment and renewal.

verses.text: And rain fell upon the earth forty days and forty nights.
verses.comment: Forty days and nights link to later periods of testing and transformation—a theme fulfilled in Christ’s fasting and in spiritual renewal.

verses.text: On that very day Noah and his sons, Shem and Ham and Japheth, and Noah’s wife and the three wives of his sons with them, entered the ark,
verses.comment: All who enter are named, signifying both historical continuity and emphasis on ordered household. The three sons prefigure the spread of humanity.

verses.text: along with every animal according to its kind, all livestock according to their kinds, and every creeping thing that creeps on the earth according to its kind, and every bird according to its kind, every bird, every winged creature.
verses.comment: The repeated phrase ‘according to its kind’ echoes the creation narrative, showing that the flood is a re-creation episode.

verses.text: They went into the ark with Noah, two and two of all flesh in which there was the breath of life.
verses.comment: ‘Breath of life’ connects to the original act of creation. Preservation of life foreshadows spiritual regeneration and later themes of baptism.

verses.text: And those who went in, male and female of all flesh, went in as God had commanded him. And the LORD shut him in.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is emphasized—the LORD himself closes the ark. This is an image of divine protection and election.

verses.text: The flood continued for forty days on the earth. The waters increased and lifted up the ark, so that it rose high above the earth.
verses.comment: The elevation of the ark is a powerful metaphor for salvation granted by grace—foreshadows spiritual ascent in Christ.

verses.text: The waters prevailed and increased greatly on the earth, and the ark floated on the surface of the waters.
verses.comment: The ark ‘floating’ preserves life above the judgment of the waters—Old Testament prefiguring the saving power of God’s covenant.

verses.text: And the waters greatly increased on the earth, and all the high mountains under the whole heaven were covered.
verses.comment: The universal scope teaches totality of divine judgment and the extent of restoration needed for true re-creation.

verses.text: The waters rose over the mountains, covering them more than fifteen cubits deep.
verses.comment: Details of depth stress overwhelming might of judgment, showing only God-given means are able to save.

verses.text: And all flesh died that moved on the earth—birds, livestock, wild beasts, all swarming creatures that swarm on the earth, and all mankind.
verses.comment: Here the totality of judgment is clear; mankind and animal alike suffer for the corruption. Christological readings see all humanity in need of ultimate salvation.

verses.text: Everything on dry land in whose nostrils was the breath of life died.
verses.comment: Deep connection to ‘breath’ makes all life sacred. Spiritual readings see new life only through new breath—fulfilled ultimately through Christ’s resurrection.

verses.text: God blotted out every living thing that was on the face of the ground, men and animals and creeping things and birds of the heavens. They were blotted out from the earth. Only Noah was left, and those who were with him in the ark.
verses.comment: Selective survival points to the mystery of divine election and the value of belonging to the household of faith. Typologically, Noah’s deliverance in the ark is often linked to baptism (1 Peter 3:20–21), signaling spiritual rebirth.

verses.text: And the waters prevailed on the earth for one hundred and fifty days.
verses.comment: A prolonged period of judgment and waiting—a season before the dawn of new life. This pattern of waiting in faith offers an image of spiritual perseverance, purification, and hope for restoration.
